sentences: Holly Suzette Dunn (August 22, 1957 – November 14, 2016) was an American country music singer and songwriter.
section: N/A

sentences: Dunn recorded for MTM Records between 1985 and 1988, Warner Bros. Records between 1988 and 1993, and River North Records between 1995 and 1997.
section: N/A

sentences: She released 10 albums and charted 19 singles, plus two duets on the Hot Country Songs charts.
section: N/A

sentences: Two of her single releases, "Are You Ever Gonna Love Me" and "You Really Had Me Going", went to No. 1 on that chart.
section: N/A

sentences: Other songs for which she is known include "Daddy's Hands" and "Maybe I Mean Yes".
section: N/A

sentences: Dunn's brother, Chris Waters, is a songwriter and record producer, having worked with both his sister and other artists in these capacities.
section: N/A

sentences: Dunn retired from music in 2003, and died of ovarian cancer in 2016.
section: N/A
== Biography ==

sentences: Biography ==
section: == Biography ==
== Biography == | === Early years and MTM Records ===

sentences: Early years and MTM Records
section: == Biography == | === Early years and MTM Records ===
== Biography == | === Early years and MTM Records ===

sentences: Holly Suzette Dunn was born August 22, 1957.
section: == Biography == | === Early years and MTM Records ===

sentences: Her parents were a Church of Christ preacher and a landscape painter.
section: == Biography == | === Early years and MTM Records ===

sentences: While attending high school, Dunn performed in a band called Freedom Folk Singers, which toured the Southern United States.
section: == Biography == | === Early years and MTM Records ===

sentences: She attended Abilene Christian University and performed in a school-sponsored group called The Hilltoppers.
section: == Biography == | === Early years and MTM Records ===

sentences: Dunn also wrote songs with her brother, Chris Waters, who  later became a prolific songwriter in Nashville, Tennessee.
section: == Biography == | === Early years and MTM Records ===

sentences: One of their collaborations, "Out of Sight, Not Out of Mind", was recorded by Cristy Lane.
section: == Biography == | === Early years and MTM Records ===

sentences: After graduating from college, Dunn moved to Nashville, where she worked as a demo singer before both  Waters and she became songwriters at CBS Records, and then MTM Records.
section: == Biography == | === Early years and MTM Records ===

sentences: Louise Mandrell had a top-10 hit in 1984 with "I'm Not Through Loving You Yet", which the two co-wrote.
section: == Biography == | === Early years and MTM Records ===

sentences: By 1985, Dunn was signed to a record contract with MTM.
section: == Biography == | === Early years and MTM Records ===

sentences: Dunn's first two releases — "Playing for Keeps" and "My Heart Holds On" — both failed to make the Top 40 on the Hot Country Songs charts, while "Two Too Many" peaked at No. 39.
section: == Biography == | === Early years and MTM Records ===

sentences: Her first Top 10 hit came in 1986, when "Daddy's Hands", a tribute to her father, peaked at No. 7 on that chart.
section: == Biography == | === Early years and MTM Records ===

sentences: Dunn, who wrote "Daddy's Hands" single-handedly, noted that the song's success led to many fans sharing positive experiences about their own fathers with her.
section: == Biography == | === Early years and MTM Records ===

sentences: The song was included on her self-titled debut, from which it served as the final single.
section: == Biography == | === Early years and MTM Records ===

sentences: Following this song, she sang guest vocals on Michael Martin Murphey's Top 5 hit "A Face in the Crowd", from his album Americana.
section: == Biography == | === Early years and MTM Records ===

sentences: She was named the Academy of Country Music's Top New Female Vocalist in 1986, and then the winner of Country Music Association's Horizon Award in 1987.
section: == Biography == | === Early years and MTM Records ===

sentences: Her second MTM album, Cornerstone, produced three straight top-10 hits in "Love Someone Like Me", "Only When I Love", and "Strangers Again".
section: == Biography == | === Early years and MTM Records ===

sentences: Across the Rio Grande in 1988 included the singles "That's What Your Love Does to Me" and "(It's Always Gonna Be)
section: == Biography == | === Early years and MTM Records ===

sentences: Someday", before MTM Records filed for bankruptcy and closed.
section: == Biography == | === Early years and MTM Records ===
== Biography == | === Warner Bros. Records, Grand Ole Opry, River North Records ===

sentences: Warner Bros. Records, Grand Ole Opry, River North Records =
section: == Biography == | === Warner Bros. Records, Grand Ole Opry, River North Records ===
== Biography == | === Warner Bros. Records, Grand Ole Opry, River North Records ===

sentences: In 1989, Dunn moved to Warner Bros. Records' Nashville division.
section: == Biography == | === Warner Bros. Records, Grand Ole Opry, River North Records ===

sentences: Her first release for the label, The Blue Rose of Texas, produced her first number-one hit in "Are You Ever Gonna Love Me", followed by "There Goes My Heart Again" at number four.
section: == Biography == | === Warner Bros. Records, Grand Ole Opry, River North Records ===

sentences: The latter was co-written by a then-unknown Joe Diffie, who also sang backing vocals on it.
section: == Biography == | === Warner Bros. Records, Grand Ole Opry, River North Records ===

sentences: She also became a member of the Grand Ole Opry in 1989.
section: == Biography == | === Warner Bros. Records, Grand Ole Opry, River North Records ===

sentences: She also sang on Kenny Rogers' late 1990 hit "Maybe", from his album  Something Inside So Strong.
section: == Biography == | === Warner Bros. Records, Grand Ole Opry, River North Records ===

sentences: Dunn's second Warner Bros. album, Heart Full of Love, was released in 1990.
section: == Biography == | === Warner Bros. Records, Grand Ole Opry, River North Records ===

sentences: Although its lead single "My Anniversary for Being a Fool" failed to make the top 40, the followup "You Really Had Me Going" became her second and final number-one hit, while the title track was a top-20 hit.
section: == Biography == | === Warner Bros. Records, Grand Ole Opry, River North Records ===

sentences: In 1991, Dunn released her first greatest hits package, Milestones: Greatest Hits.
section: == Biography == | === Warner Bros. Records, Grand Ole Opry, River North Records ===

sentences: It included the new release "Maybe I Mean
section: == Biography == | === Warner Bros. Records, Grand Ole Opry, River North Records ===

sentences: Yes", which became controversial due to some listeners interpreting the song as condoning date rape.
section: == Biography == | === Warner Bros. Records, Grand Ole Opry, River North Records ===

sentences: As a result, Dunn asked for the single to be withdrawn from rotation.
section: == Biography == | === Warner Bros. Records, Grand Ole Opry, River North Records ===

sentences: Her final Warner Bros. release, Getting It Dunn, failed to produce a top-40 hit, and she exited the label in 1993.
section: == Biography == | === Warner Bros. Records, Grand Ole Opry, River North Records ===

sentences: Dunn signed to River North Records in 1995 and released two albums for the label: Life and Love and All the Stages in 1995 and Leave One Bridge Standing two years later.
section: == Biography == | === Warner Bros. Records, Grand Ole Opry, River North Records ===

sentences: The former produced her final chart entry in "I Am Who I Am".
section: == Biography == | === Warner Bros. Records, Grand Ole Opry, River North Records ===

sentences: Shortly before the release of Leave One Bridge Standing, she joined country music radio station WWWW in Detroit, Michigan, as morning show co-host.
section: == Biography == | === Warner Bros. Records, Grand Ole Opry, River North Records ===

sentences: It was not her first time behind the radio mike, as she had served as a DJ during her college years.
section: == Biography == | === Warner Bros. Records, Grand Ole Opry, River North Records ===

sentences: However, the decision forced her to give up touring for a time.
section: == Biography == | === Warner Bros. Records, Grand Ole Opry, River North Records ===

sentences: Later, she co-hosted Opry Backstage on the Nashville Network in 1999–2002.
section: == Biography == | === Warner Bros. Records, Grand Ole Opry, River North Records ===
== Retirement (2003) ==

sentences: Retirement (2003)
section: == Retirement (2003) ==
== Retirement (2003) ==

sentences: In 2003, Dunn announced her retirement from her musical career and released her final album, Full Circle, which was her one and only gospel album, to devote full-time to her other passion, art.
section: == Retirement (2003) ==

sentences: Her paintings deal primarily with subjects from the Southwestern United States.
section: == Retirement (2003) ==
== Death ==

sentences: Death ==
section: == Death ==

sentences: On November 14, 2016, Dunn died of ovarian cancer in Albuquerque, New Mexico, at age 59.
section: == Death ==

sentences: She was survived by her wife, Melissa Taylor, and her brothers, Chris, Jerry and Rodney.
section: == Death ==
